primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in human history and the human heart to rescue the 'wretched' and 'poor' (soteriological) and to transform the 'rich' into agents of justice (ethical).

tekstueel_bewijs: He loves us too much to leave us the way we are
God is at work loosening our grip

object.identificatie: The 'Poor' (both economically and spiritually) / Salvation and Transformation
tekstueel_bewijs: so that by his poverty you might become rich

zender.identificatie: The Triune God / The Prophetic Word (Amos)
tekstueel_bewijs: the Lord whose Word we proclaim
the Lord... sent by the Lord to the cities
receiving from the depth of the Lord’s bounty
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: Does hearer identify with Subject or Receiver?

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The Gospel Story / The Church Community
tekstueel_bewijs: the telling of the Bible story
helper.rol_van_god: God is both Subject and the source of Help.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin / The 'Mean Spirit' of Culture / Self-interest / Death (implied)
tekstueel_bewijs: a mean spirit abroad in the land
selfish, turned inward, focused on our own wishes
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but a 'spirit' and 'moral poverty' that requires a Savior to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The theologically mature congregation responds to the Gospel by practicing justice and seeing the poor.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Congregation (as a response to the Primary Subject)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ethical response (Program 2) is explicitly framed as a 'fruit' or 'result' of the Primary Program (Grace).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has consigned all men to disobedience
He in his infinite plenitude has turned to me
God is at work loosening our grip
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we can never forget to repeat the story
you who trample upon the needy

voorbeelden: we can never forget to repeat the story
I want to give you my very best
As a theologically mature congregation, you will easily recognize...
While we were still helpless, Christ died
He loves us too much to leave us the way we are

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human 'helplessness' (lack of power) and God's 'plenitude' (divine power/competence) as the engine of change.

primaire_tegenstelling.niet_s1: Self-sufficiency / 'God helps those who help themselves'

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the 'No Condemnation' (S1) to the 'Judgment' of Amos (S2), then resolves by identifying the hearer as 'The Poor' (~S1) who receives Grace (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ takes the poverty/judgment (S2) so the wretch (~S1) receives the riches (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; the judgment of Amos is presented as a real threat to the 'houses of ivory'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently maintains God as the primary actor. Even the call to justice is framed as God 'loosening our grip' rather than a purely human effort.

indicatoren_moralisme.indicator: Potential Exemplarism in mentioning Whitney North Seymour
indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: the largeness of soul he exhibited

indicatoren_genade.indicator: Explicit rejection of 'God helps those who help themselves'
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: definitively contradicted by St. Paul’s explicit words
though he was rich, yet for your sake he became poor

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Historical figures (Seymour) and the congregation's history are used, but they are explicitly labeled as 'fruits of the Spirit' rather than models to imitate by will.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God acts through these figures.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-construction; gratitude-based motivation for justice.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic sanctification (God works in the believer).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'bedrock' of justification to the 'prophetic' call to justice is seamless because justice is presented as the overflow of grace.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'No Condemnation' and Amos's 'I hate your feasts'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Christ died for the ungodly... by his poverty you might become rich.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit grants the 'Pouvoir' (power) to love the neighbor by softening the heart.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; sin is 'moral poverty' and being 'turned inward'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is powered by God's initiative. The hearer is positioned as a 'helpless' recipient who is empowered by the 'Sender' to act in a secondary program of justice.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon successfully balances the 'Devoir' of Amos with the 'Pouvoir' of the Gospel.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in maintaining the 'Grammar of Grace' while addressing rigorous social and ethical demands.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'valedictory' tone, Greimas reveals that the structural 'hero' is Christ, not the departing rector.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the historical Amos; semiotics shows how Amos functions as a 'Sender' of divine values to the modern 'Receiver'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas highlights the 'Subject-Switch' where Christ takes the actantial role of the 'Poor' to transfer 'Riches' to the 'Receiver'.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'theologically mature' congregation as a collective actant that has already moved through a previous narrative program of renewal.
